The Dartmouth Summer Research Project on Artificial Intelligence, held in 1956, is widely regarded as the founding event of artificial intelligence as a field. Organized primarily by John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, Nathaniel Rochester, and Claude Shannon, this six-week workshop convened leading researchers at Dartmouth College to explore the conjecture that "every aspect of learning or any other feature of intelligence can in principle be so precisely described that a machine can be made to simulate it." The conference aimed to foster collaboration and lay the groundwork for a new scientific discipline dedicated to creating intelligent machines.

Although the workshop didn't produce immediate breakthroughs comparable to later AI advancements, it was crucial in establishing the vision, terminology, and core research directions for artificial intelligence. It brought together the pioneers who would shape the field for decades, fostering a community and solidifying AI as a distinct area of study. The Dartmouth Conference set the ambitious goals and optimistic spirit that fueled the initial wave of AI research, defining key problems like natural language processing, neural networks, and symbolic reasoning that remain central to the field today.
